David,

That's great in an ideal world. Unfortunately, my team has found that we
must run our tests inside of the weblogic application server to work around
several bugs. One in particular concerns the way CLOBs are dealt with by
JDBC and RMI. To keep the JDBC driver from making an RMI call we had to be
running within the application server itself. Additionally, the transaction
and JNDI services provided by weblogic are integral to our application and
not exactly easy to stub out or replace. In the end, running within the
application server was simpler than running apart from it. I would like to
separate ourselves from weblogic at some point so if anyone else has
encountered these same problems I would be interested in hearing how you
dealt with them...

Chris Eppstein

Just write unit tests using junit to test objects in isolation.  Once
you have many tests for all you separate functionality, then think about
how to test inside a application server.

Generally testing inside an application server is more difficult and
should not be your first goal for unit testing.

Jason Rogers wrote:

> A.P.
>
> There is a lot of documentation and plenty of examples hanging around
that
> would give you a place to start.  Look at JUnit's tests for instance.
Look
> at the sample Money tests that are published with JUnit.  Go to
junit.org,
> or the junit wiki, or the SourceForge site, etc.  I think it would be
a good
> idea for you to try learning what you can from the documentation and
> examples that already exist, then, when you have more specific
questions,
> ask the group.
>
> It isn't that we are unwilling to answer questions, it's just that I
think
> most people expect that new comers will put forth some effort in
addressing
> the learning curve.  Personaly, I don't expect you to make yourself
> completely versed in JUnit, I simply expect you to familiarize
yourself with
> the product enough to be able to ask intelligent questions about it.
>
> Try to understand what an Assert is, what a TestCase is, what a
TestResult
> is, what a TestRunner is...  These are the basics.  (Actually, you
could
> even skip TestResult for now.)  Then, if you have a class that you
already
> know you want to write tests for (or you are doing test first design
and
> have an idea of the class you will be writing) tell us about it.  We
will
> then have a common language for describing how to write the tests --
JUnit's
> framework!
>
> I hope you don't take this email offensively.  I understand that it is
> sometimes overwhelming to learn a new product (JUnit), not to mention
a new
> paradigm (unit testing or testing in general).  I only hope to guide
you to
> some possible good starting places.
>
> -Jason
